page.title: 05More Ecology-the Butley Area
page.content: This area has one of the lowest rainfall averages in the country.It is not recognised for extremes in temperature because of its proximity to the sea. The air is always fresh and bracing, and is almost free from pollution of any kind, being far away from cities or major industries. The noise from the nearby Air Bases is on occasions annoying. There are many footpaths and bridleways which afford superb views of the varied river landscape - the marshes and the broad tidal river with its wealth of birds especially the Avocet which breeds on Havergate island nearby, and the samphire which grows in abundance on the saltings. Rushes used for thatching grow at the river's edge. The many dykes which have drained the marshes abound in eel.
